intro: Eriogonum jamesii var. neomexicanum, commonly known as the New Mexico biscuit flower, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States. It is a member of the buckwheat family (Polygonaceae) and is characterized by its clustered, pinkish-white flowers that bloom in late spring. The plant typically grows in rocky soils and arid environments, showcasing its adaptability to harsh conditions. It has slender, branched stems and small, lance-shaped leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. This species is valued for its ornamental appeal and ecological importance in supporting pollinators.
